summary.long: Ezra is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The promise the Lord had spoken through Jeremiah was about to come true in Cyrus’ first year as king of Persia. The Lord inspired the king to make this announcement throughout his whole kingdom and then to put it in writing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what King Cyrus of Persia says: The Lord God of heaven has given me all the kingdoms of the world. Then he ordered me to build a temple for him in Jerusalem (which is in Judah).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God be with all of you who are his people. You may go to Jerusalem (which is in Judah) and build a temple for the Lord God of Israel. He is the God who is in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All who choose to remain behind, wherever they may be living, should provide the people who are leaving with silver, gold, supplies, livestock, and freewill offerings to be used in God’s temple in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the heads of the families of Judah and Benjamin, the priests, and the Levites—everyone God had inspired—came forward to rebuild the Lord’s temple in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All their neighbors who were remaining behind provided them with articles made from silver and gold, supplies, livestock, and valuable gifts besides everything that was freely offered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Cyrus brought out the utensils belonging to the Lord’s temple. Nebuchadnezzar had taken these utensils from Jerusalem and put them in the temple of his own god.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Cyrus of Persia put the treasurer Mithredath in charge of bringing them out. So Mithredath made a list of them for Prince Sheshbazzar of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the inventory:
gold dishes … 30
silver dishes … 1,000
knives … 29
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
gold bowls … 30
other silver bowls … 410
other utensils … 1,000
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The gold and silver utensils totaled … 5,400.
Sheshbazzar took all these utensils with him when the exiles left Babylon to go to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the people in the province. They were the ones who left the place where the exiles had been taken captive. (King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon had taken them to Babylon.) These exiles returned to Jerusalem and Judah. All of them went to their own cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They went with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Seraiah, Reelaiah, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispar, Bigvai, Rehum, and Baanah.
This is the number of Israelite men from the people in exile:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the descendants of Parosh … 2,172
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Shephatiah … 372
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Arah … 775
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Pahath Moab, that is, of Jeshua and Joab … 2,812
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Elam … 1,254
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Zattu … 945
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Zaccai … 760
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Bani … 642
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Bebai … 623
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Azgad … 1,222
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Ater, that is, Hezekiah … 98
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Bezai … 323
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Jorah … 112
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Hashum … 223
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Gibbar … 95
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Bethlehem … 123
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Netophah … 56
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Anathoth … 128
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Azmaveth … 42
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Kiriath Jearim, Chephirah, and Beeroth … 743
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Ramah and Geba … 621
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Michmas … 122
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Bethel and Ai … 223
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Nebo … 52
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Magbish … 156
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of the other Elam … 1,254
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Harim 320
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Lod, Hadid, and Ono … 725
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Jericho … 345
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Senaah … 3,630
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These priests returned from exile:
the descendants of Jedaiah (through the family of Jeshua) … 973
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Immer … 1,052
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Pashhur … 1,247
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of Harim … 1,017
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These Levites returned from exile:
the descendants of Jeshua and Kadmiel, that is, of Hodaviah … 74
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These singers returned from exile:
the descendants of Asaph … 128
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These gatekeepers returned from exile:
the descendants of Shallum, Ater, Talmon, Akkub, Hatita, and Shobai … 139
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These temple servants returned from exile: the descendants of Ziha, Hasupha, Tabbaoth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Keros, Siaha, Padon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lebanah, Hagabah, Akkub,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hagab, Shalmai, Hanan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Giddel, Gahar, Reaiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rezin, Nekoda, Gazzam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzza, Paseah, Besai,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asnah, Meunim, Nephusim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bakbuk, Hakupha, Harhur,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bazluth, Mehida, Harsha,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barkos, Sisera, Temah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Neziah, and Hatipha.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These descendants of Solomon’s servants returned from exile: the descendants of Sotai, Hassophereth, Peruda,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jaalah, Darkon, Giddel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shephatiah, Hattil, Pochereth Hazzebaim, and Ami.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The temple servants and the descendants of Solomon’s servants totaled 392.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following people came from Tel Melah, Tel Harsha, Cherub, Addan, and Immer, but they couldn’t prove they were Israelites on the basis of their father’s family or their genealogy:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the descendants of Delaiah, Tobiah, and Nekoda. These people totaled 652.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These descendants of the priests couldn’t prove their families were Israelites: the descendants of Hobaiah, Hakkoz, and Barzillai (who had married one of the daughters of Barzillai from Gilead and took that family name).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These people searched for their family names in the genealogical records, but their names couldn’t be found there. For this reason they were considered contaminated and couldn’t be priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The governor told them not to eat any of the most holy food until a priest could use the Urim and Thummim  to settle the problem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole assembly totaled 42,360.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition to the male and female servants who numbered 7,337, they also had 200 male and female singers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had 736 horses, 245 mules,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 435 camels, and 6,720 donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When some of the heads of the families came to the Lord’s temple in Jerusalem, they contributed freewill offerings to help rebuild God’s temple on its former site.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They contributed as much as they could to the treasury for this work: 1,030 pounds of gold, 5,740 pounds of silver, and 100 robes for the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests, the Levites, some of the people, the singers, the gatekeepers, and the temple servants settled in their own cities. All the other Israelites settled in their own cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the seventh month came, the people gathered together in Jerusalem. (The Israelites had already settled in their cities.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jozadak’s son Jeshua and his relatives who were priests and Shealtiel’s son Zerubbabel and his relatives built an altar for the God of Israel. They built it in order to sacrifice burnt offerings. They followed the directions written in Moses’ Teachings. (Moses was a man of God).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they rebuilt the altar on its original site, though they were afraid of the people in the neighboring regions. They sacrificed burnt offerings on it to the Lord every morning and evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Following the written directions, they celebrated the Festival of Booths. Each day they sacrificed the required number of burnt offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that, they sacrificed the daily burnt offerings, the offerings for the New Moon Festival and all the other holy festivals of the Lord, and all the freewill offerings brought to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They started to bring these burnt offerings to the Lord on the first day of the seventh month, even though the foundation of the Lord’s temple had not yet been laid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they gave money to the stonecutters and carpenters. Then they gave food, drink, and olive oil to the men from Sidon and Tyre in exchange for cedar, which the men would bring by sea from Lebanon to Joppa as King Cyrus of Persia had authorized them to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zerubbabel (who was Shealtiel’s son), Jeshua (who was Jozadak’s son), and the rest of the Jews, (the priests, Levites, and all the others who had come back from exile to Jerusalem) began to rebuild the temple. This happened in the second month of the second year following their return to the site of God’s house in Jerusalem. They began by appointing the Levites who were at least 20 years old to direct the work on the Lord’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeshua with his sons and relatives and Kadmiel with his sons who were Judah’s descendants joined Henadad’s family and their sons and relatives, the Levites, in directing those working on God’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The builders laid the foundation of the Lord’s temple. Then the priests who were dressed in their robes took their places with trumpets, and the Levites who were Asaph’s descendants took their places with cymbals to praise the Lord according to the instructions of King David of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As they praised and gave thanks to the Lord, they sang antiphonally:
“He is good; his mercy toward Israel endures forever.”
Then all the people shouted, “Praise the Lord,” because the foundation for the house of the Lord had been laid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But many of the priests, Levites, and the heads of the families who were old enough to have seen the first temple with their own eyes began to sob when they saw the foundation of this temple. Many others shouted for joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one could distinguish between the joyful shouts and the loud sobbing because the people were shouting so loudly. The noise was heard from far away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the enemies of Judah and Benjamin heard that the people who returned from exile were building a temple for the Lord God of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they approached Zerubbabel and the heads of the families. They told them, “We want to help you build because we worship the same God you worship. We have been sacrificing to him  since the time of King Esarhaddon of Assyria, who brought us here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Zerubbabel, Jeshua, and the rest of the heads of Israel’s families told them, “It isn’t right for your people and our people to build a temple for our God together. We must build it alone for the Lord God of Israel, as King Cyrus of Persia ordered us to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of that region discouraged the people of Judah and made them afraid to continue building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They bribed officials to keep the people of Judah from carrying out their plans throughout the reign of King Cyrus of Persia until the reign of King Darius of Persia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Xerxes began to rule, the enemies of Judah and Jerusalem wrote a letter in which they made an accusation against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bishlam, Mithredath, Tabeel, and the rest of their group wrote to him when Artaxerxes was king of Persia. The letter was written with the Aramaic script and translated into the Aramaic language.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehum the commander and Shimshai the scribe wrote another letter against the people of Jerusalem to King Artaxerxes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time, Rehum the commander and Shimshai the scribe were with the others of their group—the people from Denya, Partakka, Tarpel, Persia, Erech, Babylon, Susa, (that is, those of Elam),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the rest of the people whom the great and noble Assurbanipal deported. (Assurbanipal settled them in the cities of Samaria and the rest of the lands west of the Euphrates River.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the copy of the letter they sent to him:
To King Artaxerxes,
From your servants, the people west of the Euphrates:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your Majesty, you should know that the Jews who came to us from you are now in Jerusalem. They are rebuilding that rebellious and wicked city. They are close to finishing the walls. The foundations are already in place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You should also know that if this city is rebuilt and its walls are finished, the Jews will no longer pay taxes, fees, and tolls.
Ultimately, this will hurt the king’s income.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, because we are paid by your palace, it isn’t right for us to watch something happen that will dishonor the king. So we are sending this letter to inform you
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that you should search the official records of your predecessors. You will find in those official records that this city has been rebellious and has been a threat to kings and provinces. This city has a history of rebelliousness. That’s why this city was destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We want the king to know that if this city is rebuilt and its walls are finished, you will have nothing left of your province west of the Euphrates River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the king sent this reply:
To Rehum the commander, Shimshai the scribe, and the rest of their group living in Samaria, and to others west of the Euphrates River: I wish you peace and prosperity!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The letter you sent me has been read word for word in my presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave the order, and a search was made. I discovered that this city has a long history of uprisings against kings. Its inhabitants are guilty of treason and rebellion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jerusalem has had powerful kings who have ruled the whole province west of the Euphrates. Taxes, fees, and tolls were paid to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So order these men to stop rebuilding. Keep this city from being rebuilt until I give the order.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be careful not to neglect your duty in this matter. Why should I, the king, suffer any more harm?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehum the commander, Shimshai the scribe, and their group hurried to Jerusalem after hearing a copy of King Artaxerxes’ letter. They forced the Jews to stop rebuilding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the work on God’s temple in Jerusalem was stopped. Nothing more was done until Darius’ second year as king of Persia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet Haggai and Zechariah, grandson of Iddo, prophesied to the Jews in Judah and Jerusalem in the name of Israel’s God, who was over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zerubbabel, who was Shealtiel’s son, and Jeshua, who was Jozadak’s son, began to rebuild God’s temple in Jerusalem. God’s prophets were with them and supported them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the same time, Governor Tattenai from the province west of the Euphrates River, Shethar Bozenai, and their group went to the Jews and asked them, “Who gave you permission to rebuild this temple and finish its walls?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also asked the Jews for the names of the men who were working on this building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the leaders of the Jews were under God’s watchful eye. They couldn’t be stopped until Darius received a report and sent a reply to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here is a copy of the letter Governor Tattenai from the province west of the Euphrates River, Shethar Bozenai and his group (the Persians west of that river) sent to King Darius.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They sent him the following report:
To King Darius,
We wish you peace and prosperity in everything you do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your Majesty should know that we went to the province of Judah, to the temple of the great God. The temple is being built with large stones and with wooden beams laid in its walls. The builders are doing an excellent job and making rapid progress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We asked their leaders the following question: “Who gave you permission to rebuild this temple and finish its walls?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For your information, we also asked them for their names so that we would have a record of the men who were their leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This was their reply to us:
“We are the servants of the God of heaven and earth. We are rebuilding the temple that was originally built many years ago by a great king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But because our ancestors made the God of heaven angry, he handed them over to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon (a Chaldean). So Nebuchadnezzar destroyed this temple and deported its people to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “However, in the first year of the reign of King Cyrus of Babylon, Cyrus gave permission for God’s temple to be rebuilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, Cyrus took out of a temple in Babylon the gold and silver utensils that belonged to God’s temple. (Nebuchadnezzar had taken them out of God’s temple in Jerusalem and brought them into a temple in Babylon.) Cyrus gave them to a man named Sheshbazzar, whom he had made governor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cyrus told him, ‘Take these utensils. Place them in the temple in Jerusalem. Rebuild God’s temple on its original site.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Sheshbazzar laid the foundation of God’s temple in Jerusalem. The temple has been under construction from that time until now, but it still isn’t finished.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If it pleases Your Majesty, allow someone to search the king’s archives in Babylon to determine whether King Cyrus gave permission for the temple of God to be rebuilt in Jerusalem. Then please send us Your Majesty’s decision on this matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Darius gave the order to search the library where the archives were stored in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A scroll was found in the palace of Ecbatana, which is in the province of Media. This was written on it:
MEMORANDUM
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Date: Cyrus’ first year as king
From: King Cyrus
Subject: God’s temple in Jerusalem
The temple should be rebuilt as a place to offer sacrifices. Its foundation should be laid. It should be 90 feet high and 90 feet wide
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: with three rows of large stones and a row of wood. The king’s palace will pay for it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, Cyrus took out of a temple in Babylon the gold and silver utensils that belonged to God’s temple. (Nebuchadnezzar had taken them out of God’s temple in Jerusalem and brought them into a temple in Babylon.) They should be returned to their proper place in the temple in Jerusalem. You should put each one in God’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Governor Tattenai from the province west of the Euphrates, Shethar Bozenai, and those of your group (the Persians west of the river):
You must stay away from there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t interfere with the work on God’s temple. Let the governor of the Jews and the leaders of Judah rebuild God’s temple on its original foundation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am issuing this decree about how you must help the Jewish leaders rebuild God’s temple:
The cost for this should be paid out of the king’s own money from the taxes on the province west of the Euphrates. Full payment should be made to these men so that the work is not interrupted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, whatever the priests in Jerusalem need for burnt offerings to the God of heaven—young bulls, rams, lambs, wheat, salt, wine, and olive oil—should be provided for them each day. Make sure that nothing is omitted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they can offer sacrifices that please the God of heaven and pray for the life of the king and his sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am also issuing a decree that if anyone tampers with my orders, that person should be impaled on a beam torn from his own house and his house should be turned into a pile of rubble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May the God whose name is worshiped there cause the downfall of each king and nation who tries to tamper with my orders or tries to destroy the temple of the God in Jerusalem.
I, Darius, have issued a decree. It’s to be carried out exactly as ordered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Governor Tattenai from the province west of the Euphrates River, Shethar Bozenai, and their group did exactly what King Darius had ordered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Jewish leaders continued to make progress because of the message from the prophet Haggai and Zechariah, the grandson of Iddo. They finished building as the God of Israel had ordered and as Cyrus, Darius, and Artaxerxes (the kings of Persia) had ordered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This temple was finished on the third day of the month of Adar in the sixth year of King Darius’ reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Israel, the priests, the Levites, and the others who had returned from exile celebrated at the dedication of God’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the dedication of God’s temple, they sacrificed 100 bulls, 200 rams, and 400 lambs. They sacrificed 12 male goats as an offering for sin, one goat for each of the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests were assigned to their divisions and the Levites to their groups to lead the worship of God in Jerusalem by following the directions written in the Book of Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fourteenth day of the first month, those who had returned from exile celebrated the Passover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since the priests and Levites had cleansed themselves, all of them were now clean. They killed the Passover lambs for all the people who had returned from exile, for the rest of the priests, and for themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The lambs were eaten by the Israelites who had returned from exile and by all who had separated themselves from the unclean practices of the non-Jews in the land to worship the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So for seven days they celebrated the Festival of Unleavened Bread because the Lord had made them joyful. The Lord had made the king of Assyria change his mind so that he supported the people in their work on the temple of God, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After these things, during the reign of King Artaxerxes of Persia, Ezra left Babylon.
Ezra was the son of Seraiah, who was the son of Azariah, who was the son of Hilkiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who was the son of Shallum, who was the son of Zadok, who was the son of Ahitub,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who was the son of Amariah, who was the son of Azariah, who was the son of Meraioth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who was the son of Zerahiah, who was the son of Uzzi, who was the son of Bukki,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who was the son of Abishua, who was the son of Phinehas, who was the son of Eleazer, who was the son of Aaron (the first priest).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a scribe, Ezra was an expert in Moses’ Teachings, which the Lord God of Israel had given. The king gave Ezra everything he requested because the Lord his God was guiding him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some Israelites (including priests, Levites, singers, gatekeepers, and temple servants) went to Jerusalem in Artaxerxes’ seventh year as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In that same year in the fifth month, Ezra arrived in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had left Babylon on the first day of the first month, and on the first day of the fifth month, he arrived in Jerusalem, since his God was good to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ezra was determined to study the Lord’s Teachings, live by them, and teach their rules and regulations in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is a copy of the letter that King Artaxerxes gave Ezra the priest and scribe, a man with a thorough knowledge of the Lord’s commands and laws for Israel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From: Artaxerxes, king of kings
To: Ezra the priest, a scribe for the Teachings of the God of Heaven:
I wish you peace and prosperity!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have issued a decree that any Israelites who are in my kingdom and want to go with you to Jerusalem may go. This also includes the priests and Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, the king, and my seven advisers are sending you to evaluate the situation in Judah and Jerusalem on the basis of your God’s Teachings, which you hold in your hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, you must take the silver and gold that the king and his advisers willingly contributed to the God of Israel, the God whose temple is in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take any silver and gold that you find in the whole province of Babylon when you take the gifts contributed by the people and the priests. They willingly contributed these gifts for the temple of their God in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must use this money to buy bulls, rams, lambs, grain, and wine to offer on the altar of the temple of your God in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and your relatives may do whatever you think is right with the rest of the silver and gold. However, what you do must conform to the will of your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The utensils that have been given to you so that they can be used in your God’s temple must all be presented to the God of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may use the king’s treasury to pay for anything else that you must provide for your God’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, King Artaxerxes, order all the treasurers in the province west of the Euphrates River to do exactly what Ezra the priest, a scribe for the Teachings of the God of Heaven, asks you to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may give him up to 7,500 pounds of silver, 100 measures of wheat, 600 gallons of wine, 600 gallons of olive oil, and as much salt as he needs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whatever the God of heaven has commanded must be carried out in detail for the temple of the God of heaven. Why should God become angry with the king’s empire and his sons?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, we are notifying you that you are forbidden to make any priest, Levite, singer, gatekeeper, servant, or worker in the temple of this God pay any taxes, fees, or tolls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You, Ezra, using your God’s wisdom—the Teachings you hold in your hands—will appoint judges and administrators for all the people who know your God’s Teachings and live in the province west of the Euphrates River. In addition, you will teach anyone who doesn’t know the Teachings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever will not strictly follow your God’s Teachings and the king’s orders should be promptly exiled, have his goods confiscated, be imprisoned or be sentenced to die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, Ezra, said: Thanks be to the Lord God of our ancestors. He put this into the king’s mind to make the Lord’s temple in Jerusalem beautiful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made the king, his advisers, and all the king’s powerful officials treat me kindly.
I was encouraged because the Lord my God was guiding me. So I gathered leaders in Israel to go with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the leaders of the families and the genealogy of those who left Babylon with me during the reign of King Artaxerxes:
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
from the family of Pahath Moab:
Eliehoenai, son of Zerahiah, with 200 males
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I had this group gather by the river that flows to Ahava, and we camped there for three days. I noticed laypeople and priests there, but I didn’t find any Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I sent for Eliezer, Ariel, Shemaiah, Elnathan, Jarib, Elnathan, Nathan, Zechariah, and Meshullam (who were leading men) and for Joiarib and Elnathan (who were wise).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I sent them to Iddo, the leader in Casiphia. I told them to tell Iddo and his relatives, the temple servants in Casiphia, that they should bring us men who can serve in our God’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God was guiding us, so Iddo and his relatives brought us someone competent, Sherebiah, who was a descendant of Mahli, Levi, and Israel. They brought us 18 of Sherebiah’s sons and relatives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also brought Hashabiah, Jeshaiah (who was a descendant of Merari), 20 of Jeshaiah’s relatives and their sons,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and 220 temple servants. They were descended from the temple servants whom David and his officials had appointed to work for the Levites. These were all listed by name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I announced a fast there at the Ahava River so that we might humble ourselves in the presence of our God to ask him for a safe journey for ourselves, for our little ones, and for all our goods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I was ashamed to ask the king for an armed escort with cavalry to help us against an enemy attack on the way. We had already told the king, “Our God works things out for the good of everyone who dedicates his life to serving him, but his power and his anger oppose everyone who abandons him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we fasted and asked our God for a safe journey, and he answered our prayer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I selected 12 leaders from the priests—Sherebiah, Hashabiah, and 10 of their relatives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I weighed for them the silver, the gold, and the utensils. These were the contributions that the king, his advisers, his officials, and all the Israelites had contributed for our God’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I weighed the contributions for them to guard: about 24 tons of silver, 100 silver utensils weighing 150 pounds apiece, 7,500 pounds of gold,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 20 gold bowls weighing 18 pounds apiece, and two utensils of fine polished bronze that were as precious as gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I told them, “You and the utensils are holy to the Lord. The silver and gold are freewill offerings to the Lord God of your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Guard them carefully. In Jerusalem, inside the storerooms of the Lord’s temple, weigh these items. Do this in front of the chief priests, Levites, and the leaders of Israel’s families.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the priests and the Levites took charge of the silver, the gold, and the utensils. They were responsible for bringing these items to the temple of our God in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then we left the Ahava River on the twelfth day of the first month to go to Jerusalem. God was guiding us, and he rescued us from our enemies and from ambushes along the way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we reached Jerusalem, we rested for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fourth day we weighed the silver, the gold, and the utensils in our God’s temple. We put them under the supervision of Meremoth, son of the priest Uriah, as well as Eleazar, the son of Phinehas. The Levites, Jeshua’s son Jozabad, and Binnui’s son Noadiah, assisted them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything was counted and weighed, and the entire weight was recorded at that time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The exiles who had come back from captivity sacrificed burnt offerings to the God of Israel: 12 bulls for all Israel, 96 rams, 77 lambs, and 12 male goats for an offering for sin. All of these animals were burnt offerings for the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The exiles delivered the king’s orders to the king’s satraps and governors in the province west of the Euphrates River. These officials then gave their support to the people and the temple of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After these things had been done, the leaders came to me and said, “The people of Israel, including the priests and Levites, have failed to keep themselves separate from the neighboring groups of people and from the disgusting practices of the Canaanites, Hittites, Perizzites, Jebusites, Ammonites, Moabites, Egyptians, and Amorites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites and their sons have married some of these foreign women. They have mixed our holy race with the neighboring groups of people. Furthermore, the leaders and officials have led the way in being unfaithful.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I heard this, I tore my clothes in distress, pulled hair from my scalp and my beard, and sat down in shock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since the former exiles had been unfaithful, everyone who gathered around me there trembled at the words of the God of Israel. I sat in shock until the evening sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the evening sacrifice I got up from my misery, and with my clothes torn, I knelt down, stretched out my hands to the Lord my God in prayer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and said,
“I am ashamed, my God. I am embarrassed to look at you. Our sins have piled up over our heads, and our guilt is so overwhelming that it reaches heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From our ancestors’ days until now, we have been deep in guilt. Our kings and our priests have been handed over to foreign kings to be executed. We have been taken captive, robbed, and humiliated, as we still are today because of our sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, for a brief moment, the Lord our God has been kind enough to leave us a few survivors from Babylon and to give us a secure hold on his holy place. Our God has made our eyes light up and has given us new opportunities while we were slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We are slaves, but our God hasn’t abandoned us in our slavery. Instead, he has made the kings of Persia treat us kindly. He did this to give us an opportunity to rebuild our God’s temple and restore its ruins and to give us a protective wall in Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now, our God, what can we say after all this? We have abandoned your commandments!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The commandments you gave us through your servants the prophets, said, ‘The land you are going to take possession of has been polluted by its perverted people and by their disgusting practices that have filled it with wickedness from one end to another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So never let your daughters marry their sons or your sons marry their daughters, and never seek peace or trade with them. Then you will be strong, be able to eat the good things the land produces, and be able to give this land as a long-lasting inheritance to your children.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “After all that has happened to us because of the evil things we have done and because of our overwhelming guilt, you, our God, have punished us far less than we deserve and have permitted a few of us to survive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If we break your commandments again and intermarry with people doing these disgusting things, you will become even more angry with us until you finally destroy us and no survivors are left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lord God of Israel, because you are fair, a few of us continue to remain as survivors. Look at us. All of us are guilty. None of us can stand in your presence because of this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Ezra was praying, confessing these sins, crying, and throwing himself down in front of God’s temple, a large crowd of Israelite men, women, and children gathered around him. They also began to cry bitterly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Shecaniah, son of Jehiel, one of the descendants of Elam, interrupted by saying to Ezra, “We have been unfaithful to our God by marrying foreign women who came from the people around us. However, there is still hope for Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we must now make a promise to our God to get rid of all foreign women and the children born from them, as my lord Ezra and the others who tremble at the commandments of our God have advised us to do. We must do what Moses’ Teachings tell us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Get up! It’s your duty to take action. We are with you, so be strong and take action.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ezra got up and made the leaders, priests, Levites, and all the rest of Israel swear to do what they had said. So they took an oath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ezra left the front of God’s temple and went to the room of Jehohanan, son of Eliashib. Ezra didn’t eat any food or drink any water while he was there. He was mourning because these former exiles had been so unfaithful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he sent a proclamation throughout Judah and Jerusalem that all the former exiles must gather in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If any of them didn’t come within three days as the leaders and the older men had advised, then they would lose all their property and be excluded from the community of former exiles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the men of Judah and Benjamin gathered within three days in Jerusalem. On the twentieth day of the ninth month, all the people sat in the courtyard of God’s temple. They were trembling because of this matter and shivering because of the heavy rain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ezra the priest stood up and said to them, “You have been unfaithful by marrying foreign women, and now you have added to Israel’s guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Confess to the Lord God of your ancestors what you have done, and do what he wants. Separate yourselves from the people of this land and from your foreign wives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the whole assembly shouted in reply, “Yes! We will do as you say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the crowd is too large, and it’s the rainy season. We can’t take care of this outside. Besides, there are so many of us who are involved in this sin that it can’t be taken care of in a day or two.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let our leaders represent the whole community. At a set time, everyone who has married a foreign woman must meet with the leaders and judges of each city until our God’s burning anger has turned away from us in this matter.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Only Jonathan, Asahel’s son, and Jahzeiah, Tikvah’s son, opposed this. Meshullam and Shabbethai, the Levite, supported Jonathan and Jahzeiah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The former exiles did this. Ezra the priest chose men who were heads of families. He chose one from each family division. (They were all listed by name.) They sat down on the first day of the tenth month to investigate the matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By the first day of the first month, they had finished dealing with all the men who had married foreign women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Among the descendants of the priests, the following were married to foreign women: Maaseiah, Eliezer, Jarib, and Gedaliah, a descendant of Jeshua (who was Jozadak’s son) and his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shook hands as a pledge that they would get rid of their wives. They sacrificed a ram from their flock as an offering for guilt because they were guilty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of these men had married foreign women. Some of these women had given birth to children.
verses.speaker: Narrator
